narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how we process and hold our memories, including how they get passed down through the generations. I also learned a lot about the root of Christianity and how the biblical stories are told and held as memories. I learned to approach projects more creatively.
I learned about how to apply a critical lens to how memory shapes culture, religion, story telling and places.
I learned how to write about films thoughtfully and how to apply memory theory to historical studies.

I learned a lot about memory studies and what this emerging field even is. I was able to learn a bit about how memory was formed at a neurological level, but the most interesting part was the formation of memory at a familial and cultural level. I was able to examine my own familial memory and have a better understanding of the use of memory as an institutional tool.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was so good! Dr. D and the TAs created an environment that was very open and honest and allowed us to intellectually engage with the materials on a deep level while also creating really funny discussions that I looked forward to. They worked really hard to adapt the class to COVID and did so very successfully (see more on that below.) They were patient and generous with their time in relation to the completion of projects and assignments and all the readings and subjects were chosen carefully and were interesting and conducive to discussion.

Strengths: really nice and laid back setting, made for a really productive yet refreshing class after a long day of Zoom, by far one of my only classes that I really wished was in person; the professor (Professor Davis or "Dr. D") is so understanding that we are students and cares about his students

Weaknesses: sometimes it can get a bit fluffy, but thats just thats how seminars are
No weaknesses. Strengths were Dr. D and Kavya and Camille, who were so engaging during seminar conversations and so willing to guide the conversation in whatever direction we naturally took.

Strengths: I loved the teaching team! I was quite vulnerable during this class because I felt so comfortable. The people in my class were also great! I enjoyed our deep discussions and how we truly were able to just learn from each other, challenge each other, and grow in our thoughts and analysis. We were also able to do our projects in any medium of our choice, and that was so great as a person interested in art and multimedia work!

Weakness: Sometimes class could be a bit stagnant if the material was overly complicated, which happened maybe twice over the whole semester.
The course was extremely well-taught, accomodating of pandemic circumstances, and provided a good balance between theory and examples.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The three main assignments of the course which initially were all going to be essays turned into more flexible projects that allowed people working virtually to approach the topics creatively and make use of the resources available. I thought that was really successful. The discussions themselves were very successful, a large part of which can be contributed to the style of facilitation by the professor and TAs. The readings were often ranked by priority which was very helpful during virtual learning when sometimes it is not possible to complete all the work by class time. Overall, I think this class was my most successful in terms of adjusting to COVID-19.

Course did probably the best out of all of mine in terms of making COVID as least sufferable as it's been. Whenever something comes up (ex: an artifact from antiquity that relates to the subtopic of memory we're discussing that week) professor or TFs would screenshare for us, they'd do the same with videos, pictures, etc.
I think the whiteboard activities were essential in idea formation and having access to people's ideas as well.
I appreciated the use of canvas discussion boards and the willingness to allow students to put a creative twist on various papers.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I absolutely would. All the topics and units layered together in really interesting ways and after discussions I often continued to talk about the topics with family and friends. The projects really allowed me to engage with the material in ways I wouldn't have normally, and I feel like I learned a lot.
Yes, this course does a phenomenal job of broadening one's mind on the intersection of memory, Christianity, and Black America.
YES, especially if you want a type of Humanities gut that makes for a pleasant experience. The workload isn't heavy, the professors and TFs are compassionate and don't just feel like robots
Yes! This class is fascinating if you have never been exposed to memory practices and is so relevant to any study of the humanities.
Of course! Please take this course if you are remotely interested in cultural or historical memory. It was thought-provoking and enriching.
This course was an excellent experience, from which I learned so much.
